item.title: What makes ransomware victims less likely to pay up?

description.#cdata-section:
There’s a good reason why ransomware gangs started exfiltrating victims’ data instead of just encrypting it: those organizations pay more. University of Twente researcher Tom Meurs and his colleagues wanted to know which factors influence victims to pay the ransom or not, and which factors have an effect on the ransom amount organizations end up paying. item.title: Longer passwords aren’t safe from intensive cracking efforts

description.#cdata-section:
88% of organizations still use passwords as their primary method of authentication, according to Specops Software. The report found that 31.1 million breached passwords had over 16 characters, showing longer passwords aren’t safe from being cracked. 40,000 admin portal accounts were found to be using ‘admin’ as a password, and only 50% of organizations scan for compromised passwords more than once a month. 123456 was the most common compromised password in KrakenLab’s new list of … More →

item.title: Essential questions for developing effective human rights policies

description.#cdata-section:
Growing environmental, social, and governance (ESG) expectations and expanding global regulation are propelling organizations to consider implementing a stand-alone human rights policy, according to Gartner. Public focus on human rights Shareholder proposals and media reports continue to put human rights concerns within companies and their supply chains under public scrutiny. item.title: Searchlight Cyber adds AI-powered language translation to simplify dark web investigations

description.#cdata-section:
Searchlight Cyber has added AI-powered language translation into its dark web investigation and monitoring products DarkIQ and Cerberus.
